narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I honestly don't really know what knowledge I gained from this course, other than law is simply not universal, to any degree. Other than that, I don't really know if I have any main takeaways, I feel like this course was just a bunch of case studies.
Analyzing court cases, the rhetoric of law, and the questions that need asking in understanding anthropological research

I developed knowledge about different legal systems in the context of various world cultures, on a variety of areas in law, and how societal beliefs play a role in the legal practices implemented within that society.

I learned about what anthropology is and how it relates to legal structure and culture. You develop skills in research writing and close reading. You learn how to deal with a lack of clear answers in the world.

This class presented me a new way of thinking about law, particularly its intersection with culture. It also introduced me to the realm of anthropology and ethnography which was certainly insightful and fascinating!
I looked at law in a different way that I hadn't before, considering it from an anthropological perspective and analyzing what law really is

We learned about what is law and how it differs across cultures. We learned about how people settle disputes across cultures and about the meaning of justice to different people. Overall, I learned how to approach things from an anthropological lens.

I learned so much about what law is, how law works in different cultures, and how the intention of law and the application of law are not always aligned. I also learned a lot about anthropological methods.

As a student who never examined anything from an anthropological perspective before, this class taught me so much. The readings were insightful and Professor Lombard was incredible with every lecture. I learned about the anthropological process and ethnographic research while digging deeper into the law that Americans value so dearly.

I developed the ability to think about a subject anthropologically, that is, in a human-centered and holistic way. I also saw how the law as a concept is something that is very much a product of its subjects.

I gained a lot of knowledge about the various ways in which law functions within the context of so many cultures. In the pursuit of legal reform in the United States, it is invaluable to have knowledge of the many ways in which law is carried out and it was so fascinating!!!!

In class, we explored cultures & case studies around the world in order to gain a better sense as to what law exactly means to them. Each week, we are given a different world to explore through readings, documentaries, guest speakers or otherwise. Because of this, the class always felt like we were getting a global scope as to what law is, as opposed to an often-jaded American perspective of law, which I enjoyed.
Analysis of legal opinions and research methods.
This course provided an insight into the realm of law from an anthropologists perspective. Walking through various research questions and cases we explored how to analyze and critique law.
I really enjoyed this course as it presented me with a wide range of case studies surrounding law that I never would have heard of otherwise.
I learned a lot about how law and morality shape everyday life and the norms of countries around the world.
I feel that I gained deeper insight into what justice means to people of different cultures and how those ideas play out in different legal systems.
insight into ways to think about problems through an anthropological lens.

I learned to look more deeply into sociopolitical issues from an anthropological perspective which gave me invaluable insight on how societal institutions shape interpersonal legal and political interactions.
I learned a huge amount about law, anthropology, culture, studying people and how different academic fields are often extremely interconnected.

I learned to think about law in a variety of contexts, cultures, and through a variety of lenses. I learned about the ethnographic and case study methods, and learned to make associations between findings like a cultural anthropologist.
Some law understanding

This course allowed me to dive deeper into what ethnography looks like, as well as other forms of anthropological research. Discussions about why we need law, why law looks the way it does, and different aspects of law like the prison system were helpful in understanding law as a part of culture but also the cultural variance of law, disputes, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Requires quite a bit of reading outside of class. What is discussed in class is extremely vague and conceptual.

The lectures could have been a little more engaging. They were basically just 30 minutes of going over the readings, and then she would tell us a story from her own research experiences, and then she would ask us if we have questions, which few people every did. Also some of the readings were just very obscure, so it just wasn't an engaging course.
Assignments not clear, ambiguous

This class was really interesting and low-stress. The workload was very manageable and still felt as though you were learning something valuable. Prof. Lombard is a compelling lecturer, and she evidently cares about students' understanding and success. She's responsive, accommodating, and instructive, and she makes efficient use of class time to get points across. I also thought the organization was particularly well-suited to an online format, especially the mode of assessment (participation, reading responses, and group projects rather than exams).

Strengths - interesting content, pleasant (virtual) atmosphere
Weaknesses - disengaging discussions, sometimes seemingly irrelevant discussions

Strengths-
Professor Lombard is passionate about anthropology and the field
Creative projects in place of midterm or final

Weaknesses- 
Easy to disengage with course materials
Easy to disengage with lectures
Readings long and can be uninteresting and difficult to follow
Expectations for projects unclear
***Group projects over zoom sound appealing for classmate engagement but in reality are difficult and frustrating to navigate given different home environments, time zones, and lack of in-person accountability. The only two projects are group projects so you rely on others for a majority percentage of your grade which is frustrating.

Strengths: engaging professor, helpful discussions, thoughtful lectures
Weaknesses: there were a lot of readings that were a bit hard to understand and I would have appreciated a bit more guidance and background on those.

Strengths: topics are interesting, projects are somewhat engaging
Weaknesses: readings are way longer than necessary, lectures are not engaging, course doesn't flow super well as far as info learned and units aren't super clearly separated

Professor Lombard is amazing and the teaching fellows were fantastic. The material is very interesting. The only think I will say is that the lectures and discussion sections sometimes felt disconnected. In discussion section we only discussed the readings and didn't talk about anything we went over in class.

The lectures and readings were both very interesting. The assignments were not too bad and were great lessons in reviewing the ethnographic readings. Fair warning, some of the readings can be very long, but most were interesting enough to engage you throughout.
This course overall was very enjoyable; one weakness was that it started at 8 am for me.

Since it was a medium sized lecture, it was easy to actively engage during class. I also enjoyed the reflection papers quite a bit. They allowed leniency in interacting with course themes and readings. As a person not familiar with law or anthropology, I always looked forward to sharing my view in these papers.
Really interesting course!

Unfortunately the virtual lecture format meant lectures were difficult to completely stay engaged with although Professor Lombard made an exceptional and appreciated effort to consistently engage the entire class. The response papers were a low stakes means to engage with the readings and I really did enjoy them. One thing however was that both large assignments were group based, while this did limit the total amount of work done, at times the group project felt difficult to showcase your own individual work and as such was very dependent on the work of everyone combined. I would rather have had one individual based assessment to balance things out.

The readings are engaging and so is lecture. 
Section was helpful as we went over the readings for each week. 

Hard that its 9am especially virtually.
lecture had barely any slides with words on it - just was professor speaking, which often wasn't engaging enough

I really like Prof. Lombard's lecture style she was always so engaged with the students and seemed so interested in all the topics. Maybe a different structure for section to facilitate more student engagement.

The course is a great survey into the kind of work that overlaps law and anthropology, but I think it could've had a clearer structure lecture to lecture in what it was we were trying to "get at," which I now know is a thing not all anthropologists do, but still--never really felt like we got near the answer as to how law was culture as much as we just posited a lot of different examples.
The strength of this course was the fascinating material, wonderful Professor and great TFs.

The group assignments in the course were fun and a great way to meet peers. I learned a lot from the people I worked with, and I think bouncing ideas off of each other in this way was very useful. The readings were interesting and engaging, and the professor's enthusiasm for cultural anthropology is infectious. The one improvement I would make would be to provide more consistent feedback. I had no idea how I was really doing in the class apart from emailed grades on singular assignments.
Too broad

Strengths: The structure of the class and assignments allows for a good amount of unstructured thoughts to be further explored. I also appreciated getting feedback on big assignments

Weaknesses: I would have liked to see less group work on big assignments because working with people who are in very different time zones made it very difficult to get work done and feel like we are producing satisfactory work because we are all rushing to get it done at a certain time. I also would have liked more clarity around big assignments because I felt that was unclear a lot of the time

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The group projects were really a successful element of the course structure. It forced me to actually connect with my peers where otherwise I would have been pretty isolated, and they were low-stress enough that it took the panic out of trying to coordinate as a group.

Succeeded - virtual class meetings and sections 
Need improvement - facilitating discussion in breakout rooms and engagement during lecture

Live lectures and section were not extremely engaging
Group projects during remote learning felt overwhelming
Instructions unclear on most assignments, details added to expectations through announcement or TA opinions in section

Successes: no technical issues, a decent level of engagement between the professor and students
Weaknesses: nothing much -- perhaps putting students into breakout rooms more often during lecture will ensure high engagement
Not much could've been done related to COVID to improve this course
I thought Professor Lombard did a great job of engaging with us throughout lecture by asking questions and putting us in breakout rooms.
I thought the live lectures were a nice way to bring the whole class together and have a real discussion about the material.
It all worked very smoothly and we even got to have many guest appearances due to the virtual nature of the course.
The practices were fairly standard, and did fairly well.
Maybe more potential interaction with prof and the TF's. Personally, I had class during office hours so I couldn't attend, but prof was really responsive when it came to emails!

Professor Lombard asked many questions to facilitate discussion in class. I also liked the use of breakout rooms. Instead of directing us with a particular question, she urged us to reflect on how the course material and themes were visible in our personal lives and share with classmates.

In regards to adjusting for COVID, I am not sure whether the group projects and response papers are a result of this. If so, they were novel and successful attempts to facilitate engagement within the class and with content. Unfortunately the early lecture meant that I myself wasnt as engaged as I could have been, and there were many who also werent as engaged.

The recorded lecture was great. 
Section also helped me engage.
sections were definitely helpful
The live lecture was good for student engagement! I appreciated the effort that Prof. Lombard put in.
The break out room chats were much appreciated!
Virtual live sections and lectures through Zoom were helpful to facilitate learning.
Not engaging

I really appreciated having the lectures recorded and all readings available free on Canvas. However, I would have liked grades to be posted on the Canvas grades tab so I could know what my progress looks like.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No I would not recommend it. The lectures were not very engaging, it requires a massive amount of reading. The projects assigned are extremely vague and they grade harsh despite giving little instruction.
Not really

Absolutely -- Prof. Lombard is one of the most accommodating and engaging professors I've had at Yale. She and the TFs made potentially complex topics seem simple, the material was fascinating, and the workload was eminently manageable. No matter what your usual field of study is, this class is an interesting, easy way to get a new perspective on things we normally take for granted or don't get to learn about.
Yes, the class covers very interesting topics; however, the lack of engagement I experienced due to disconnected and disorganized virtual learning took away from my learning experience.

No at least not virutally. The class opened my mind to laws function in society but you only get out what you put in. With a Yale workload, its easy to disengage. The group assignments and assignment details need to be redrawn for the time we're living in and clarity respectively.

Yes! It would be a good class for someone who is interested in pursuing law as the course provides you with a different lens through which to examine law and the legal system not only in America but globally as well. Professor Lombard is also incredibly kind and supportive, always passionate about her lectures and the material!

No, personally I didn't enjoy this course and don't feel that I have taken a lot of concrete information away from it. The lectures essentially consisted of the professor restating the readings and the only time I actually built on readings was during section. Projects also had very unclear expectations and we didn't receive super detailed feedback on them.
Yes definitely. It's a great introduction into anthropology as a discipline and Professor Lombard is amazing!
I would recommend this class to any student interested in challenging their assumptions about how law works both in the United States and globally.

Yes! I would definitely recommend this course to others. The other students in the class are so incredibly nice, so you meet a lot of great individuals. Professor Lombard is fantastic and the TFs were both insightful and fun to work with during discussions. The class is overall a fantastic course to take.
Yes, this course is great, informative, thought-provoking, all while not being a huge stressor or time sink.
I would! If you have an interest in expanding your knowledge of law at a cultural level, take it!

Yes. This course is an excellent choice for a novice in the field of anthropology who wants to be encouraged to relate personal experience and observations to the formation and execution of legal systems and laws. Professor Lombard is a delight and somehow always makes an 8am zoom meeting a thing to look forward to!
yes!! amazing class and Professor Lombard is great!
I would recommend this to other Yalies whether interested in law, anthropology, or neither. Its a fun way to explore history and law and get a good grasp of anthropology along the way.
I would definitely recommend this course. The content was interesting and the workload was 100% manageable.
I don't think I would. One would have to be very very interested in the subject matter to stay engaged with the course and want to participate in lecture. I found it a bit boring.
If they were interested in the topic, yes.
Yes, I would recommend the course to someone who is very interested in anthropology!
Yes, to any students deciding between anthropology and law especially this is a wonderful class. Lots of knowledge I would otherwise not have known, and Professor Lombard is great.
A must class take at Yale. If you are interested in law school, it is a must take. If you are interested in how our society works, also a must take.

Professor Lombard is absolutely fantastic. I woke up every Monday morning excited for lectures as the material was applicable to everyday life and always interesting. If you would like to have a further understanding of the legalization of life take this course!!

Yes, I would highly recommend this course if you are interested in law, culture, and anything in between. I think it would be especially helpful for people going to law school in order to help them understand that the law is not black-letter, but instead a set of informal and formal systems such as shared values.
No

This course was great and I felt it was a good introduction to a small portion of sociocultural anthropology. I enjoyed thinking critically of law and culture and law as culture throughout the course.
